questions.question:
Question 1: A child was brought with complaints of an eczematous lesion on the scalp. A biopsy from the 
lesion was taken. The cells stained positively for CD1a and CD207. What are these cells?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The image shows Langerhans 
cells with abundant, often vacuolated cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei containing linear grooves or 
folds and surrounding eosinophils. They stain positive for CD1a and S-100. They 
are intraepidermal dendritic cells. The image below shows Langerhans cells. 1267 
Sold by @itachibot Clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells leads to Langerhans cell histiocytosis, a histiocytic and 
dendritic cell neoplasm. These cells secrete factors that augment innate immune responses, and also the 
antigen-presenting cell of the skin, thereby stimulating the adaptive immune system.

questions.question:
Question 2: An elderly man presented with a rapidly growing lesion as shown below. A biopsy from this 
lesion showed malignant cells. The immunohistochemical staining was positive for CK-20. 
The tumor cells in this condition originated from which of the following cells? 1254 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of Merkel cell carcinoma. It arises from Merkel cells. These cells are located in epithelial basal cell layer and have neuroendocrine and 
mechanoreceptor functions. Merkel cell carcinoma is a rare and aggressive neuroendocrine tumor of the skin, most commonly 
found in white men and diagnosed at a mean age of 70 years. A rapidly growing, flesh-colored 1268 
Sold by @itachibot papule or plaque characterizes the disease. About 80% of the cases are seen associated with 
Merkel cell polyomavirus. Regional lymph nodes are involved in 30% of the patients and 50% will develop systemic 
disease. CK-20 is a specific marker for Merkel cell carcinoma. Wide local excision is usually 
necessary. The image below shows Merkel cell carcinoma composed of uniform small round cells having 
granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm.

questions.question:
Question 3: A histopathological examination of melanocytic nevus in a patient showed nests of large 
round pigmented cells superficially. At the deeper extent of the lesion, it showed fascicles of 
non-pigmented cells resembling neural tissue. What does this signify?

options.c: Risk of malignant transformation into melanoma

questions.explanation:
Nevus cells often become non-pigmented and resemble neural tissue as they grow deep into the 
dermis. This change is called neurotization and suggests the benign nature of the nevus. This morphological change in nevus cells occurs due to progressive loss of tyrosinase activity and 
acquisition of cholinesterase activity in deeper “nervelike” nevus cells. Melanocytic nevi (moles) are common benign neoplasms caused by acquired activating mutations 
in components of the RAS signaling pathway. Based on the location, it may be junctional nevi, intradermal nevi, or compound nevi. Melanocytic nevi are thought to progress through a series of morphologic changes over time. 
Superficial nevus cells are larger, tend to produce melanin, and grow in nests. Deeper nevus cells 
are smaller, produce little or no pigment, and appear as cords and single cells. At the deepest 
extent of the lesions, these cells often acquire fusiform contours and grow in fascicles resembling 
neural tissue (neurotization). Melanocytic nevi with neurotization indicate normal maturation change and help in 
differentiating benign nevi from melanomas (which lacks such features). 1269 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following driver mutations is not associated with given skin malignancy? 1255 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Mutations in receptor tyrosine kinase signalling pathway

questions.explanation:
The above image is suggestive of melanoma. Mutations in the hedgehog signaling pathway are 
associated with basal cell carcinoma. All other mutations are associated with melanoma. Melanoma is a highly aggressive malignancy linked to UV exposure. Most sporadic melanomas are associated with mutations in cell cycle regulators (p16/INK4a, 
CDK4), proteins in receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway (KIT, RAS, BRAF), and telomerase 
(TERT mutation). Dysplastic nevus syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition with inherited CDKN2A mutation 
that can lead to familial melanoma.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common type of melanoma?
questions.explanation:
The superficial spreading type of melanoma is the most common type of melanoma. The progression of melanoma may be described as: • Radial growth phase: the horizontal spread of melanoma within the epidermis and superficial 
dermis • Acral lentiginous - unrelated to sun exposure • Lentigo maligna (Hutchinson freckle) - sun-exposed regions • Superficial spreading (most common) • Vertical growth phase: the tumor cells invade downward into the deeper dermal layers as an 
expansile mass (nodular) 1270 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows melanoma in the radial growth phase. It shows the irregular nested and 
single-cell growth of melanoma cells within the epidermis and an underlying inflammatory 
response within the dermis. The image below shows melanoma cells that have large nuclei with irregular contours. The 
chromatin is characteristically clumped at the periphery of the nuclear membrane with prominent 
red (eosinophilic) nucleoli. 1271 
Sold by @itachibot 1272 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: An elderly European man presented with a slowly progressing lesion on his scalp for 2 years. 
Immunohistochemistry revealed tumor cells that were positive for the S-100 marker. All are 
favorable prognostic factors for his condition except: 1256 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above image is suggestive of melanoma. The absence of regression is a favorable prognostic 
factor in melanomas. Immunohistochemistry markers for melanoma are: • S-100 • HMB (Human Melanoma Black)-45 • LDH • MELAN-A Regression is defined as partial or complete disappearance of a previously documented tumor in 
the absence of therapeutic interventions or physical trauma. Microscopically, it is characterized by 
the replacement of melanoma cells by dense inflammtory cell infiltrate or dermal fibrosis. This phenomenon explains some apparent discrepancies between expected and observed 
prognosis based on tumor thickness and also the cases of metastatic melanoma with occult 
primary. Determinants of a more favorable prognosis in melanoma include: • Thinner tumor depth • No or very few mitoses (< 1 per mm2) • A brisk tumor infiltrating lymphocyte response • The absence of regression • Lack of ulceration • Absence of metastases in the sentinel lymph node

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following conditions is not associated with FGFR3 mutations?
questions.explanation:
Mutations in the FGFR3 gene are not described in melanomas. Fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR3) is a receptor tyrosine kinase. Defects in the FGFR3 gene have been associated with several conditions: • Hypochondroplasia • Thanatophoric dwarfism • Seborrheic keratosis • Acanthosis nigricans • Bladder cancer • Craniosynostosis 1273 
Sold by @itachibot • Severe achondroplasia with developmental delay and acanthosis nigricans (SADDAN)

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient presented with multiple, small, pink nodular growths on the temples. A biopsy from 
the lesion showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis? 1257 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above image shows a jigsaw puzzle appearance which is seen in 
cylindroma (turban tumor/Spiegler’s tumor). Cylindroma is a familial autosomal dominant disorder. It is due to the loss of the cylindromatosis 
gene, CYLD on chromosome 16q12-13. It has also been reported to follow radiotherapy 
epilation of the scalp. The lesions are frequently multiple, smooth, firm, pink to red, and somewhat pedunculated. They 
are mostly seen on the scalp. Histologically, it contains mosaic■like masses - a jigsaw appearance. 
Malignant transformation is very rare. Surgery is the treatment of choice. 1274 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Genetic syndromes associated with adnexal tumors: • Germline mutations in CYLD - familial cylindromatosis, familial trichoepithelioma • Brooke–Spiegler syndrome - associated with trichoepithelioma, cylindroma, spiradenoma • Muir–Torre syndrome - sebaceous adenomas • Cowden syndrome - multiple trichilemmomas

questions.question:
Question 9: Histopathological examination of a biopsy taken from a rough, scaly macular lesion from a 
patient's forearm showed neoplastic dyskeratosis. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Neoplastic dyskeratosis is seen in actinic keratosis. Dyskeratosis is premature keratinization of individual keratinocytes. These cells usually have pink 
or reddish cytoplasm. It can be benign or malignant: • Benign dyskeratosis - seen in Darier’s disease, warty dyskeratoma, and familial benign 
pemphigus • Neoplastic dyskeratosis - seen in Bowen’s disease, squamous cell carcinoma, and actinic 
keratosis Actinic keratoses usually occur in sun-damaged skin and are considered precursor lesions of 
squamous cell carcinoma. Some lesions produce so much keratin that a cutaneous horn develops. The image below shows the histology of actinic keratosis. It shows atypical basal cells, 
dyskeratotic cells, and parakeratosis in the stratum corneum (cells with a retained nucleus). 1275 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A biopsy from a chronic oropharyngeal lesion of a patient showed the following. Which of the 
following is not a risk factor for developing this condition? 1258 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above image shows keratinous pearls and atypical tumor cells suggestive of squamous cell 
carcinoma. Human papillomavirus (HPV) subtypes 5 and 8 may predispose to squamous cell 
carcinoma, but not Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma: • Exposure to UV light • HPV subtypes 5 and 8 • Epidermodysplasia verruciformis • Industrial carcinogens (tars and oils) • Chronic ulcers and draining osteomyelitis • Old burn scars (Marjolin ulcers) • Ingestion of arsenicals • Ionizing radiation • Tobacco and betel nut chewing (in the oral cavity) • Precursor lesions: • Actinic keratosis • Xeroderma pigmentosum 1276 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows an SCC lesion in the oral cavity. 1277 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 60-year-old man presents with a pearly papule over the face containing prominent dilated 
subepidermal blood vessels and surface ulceration. A histological picture of the tumor is 
shown below. All are true about the tumor except:

options.a: Incidence is increased in xeroderma pigmentosum
options.b: Presence of multiple such tumors is seen in Gorlin syndrome

questions.explanation:
The clinical presentation and histology are suggestive of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). It is a locally 
aggressive cutaneous tumor, and metastasis is very rare. It occurs in sun-exposed areas with increased incidence in the setting of immunosuppression and 
in disorders of DNA repair, such as xeroderma pigmentosum. BCCs usually present as pearly papules and locally invasive ulcers (rodent ulcers). 
Histologically, the tumor cells resemble those in the normal basal cell layer of the epidermis with 
peripheral palisading and retraction cleft. It is associated with mutations that activate the hedgehog pathway signaling. Gorlin syndrome is an autosomal-dominant disorder with multiple basal cell carcinomas, 
medulloblastomas, ovarian fibromas, and odontogenic keratocysts, pits of the palms, and soles. The image below shows the histopathology of BCC. 1278 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: The clinical picture and a biopsy from the skin lesion of a patient are shown below. This 
condition is associated with which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The clinical image shows diffuse erythema and scaling of the entire body surface (erythroderma) 
and histopathology shows the presence of lymphocytes in the epidermal cell layer 
(epidermotropism). This is suggestive of Sézary syndrome which is a disseminated and severe 
form of mycosis fungoides (cutaneous T-cell lymphoma). Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CD4+ T-cells) that presents in the skin. It 
remains localized to the skin for many years, but it may eventually evolve into a systemic 
lymphoma. The image of mycosis fungoides showing hallmark features - Sezary Lutzner cells showing 
epidermal infiltration (epidermotropism), 1279 
Sold by @itachibot

The above scenario is suggestive of urticaria pigmentosa caused by cutaneous mastocytosis. The 
Masson-Fontana stain is used to demonstrate melanin in nevus and malignant melanoma. Darier's sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa. It refers to the development 
of urticaria and erythema around the lesions after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of 
the lesion. Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin 
(H&E)–stained sections. Special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to 
visualize their granules. Stains for mast cells: • Toluidine blue • Giemsa • Tryptase • Leder stain (Chloracetate esterase) • CD 117 The image below shows mast cells stained with toluidine blue. 1280 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 40-year-old woman presents with oral ulcers and bullae over the mucosa and skin. On 
examination, the bullae are flaccid and filled with clear fluid. Histopathology of the lesion 
shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above image shows the suprabasal splitting of the epidermis (acantholysis) giving rise to 
the row of tombstones appearance. This is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. Pemphigus vulgaris is the most common type of pemphigus. It involves the mucosa and skin. 
Autoantibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3 are present. Pemphigus is a blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of 
intercellular attachments within the epidermis and mucosal epithelium. Variants of pemphigus: • Pemphigus vulgaris • Pemphigus vegetans 1281 
Sold by @itachibot • Pemphigus foliaceus - autoantibodies are against Dsg1 alone, leading to superficial, subcorneal 
blisters. • Pemphigus erythematosus • Paraneoplastic pemphigus - in association with various malignancies, most commonly 
non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.question:
Question 15: A 30-year-old woman presented with painful blisters on the skin and oral mucosa. Direct 
immunofluorescence is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the same? 1261 
Sold by @itachibot

options.c: Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature

questions.explanation:
Antibodies against hemidesmosomes is the false statement as the given image shows a 
characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of 
pemphigus vulgaris. The antibodies are against the desmosomal adhesion proteins such as 
desmogleins 1 and 3. This pattern is due to intraepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3. The first-line investigation in pemphigus vulgaris is the Tzanck smear. It allows us to visualize the 
histology by collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister that is stained with Giemsa or any 
Romanowsky stain. Tzanck cells are seen on microscopy. 1282 
Sold by @itachibot Direct immunofluorescence microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test. Antibodies against hemidesmosomes that link basal keratinocytes to the underlying basement 
membrane are seen in bullous pemphigoid.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 70-year-old woman presents with multiple tense itchy blisters on the trunk and thigh 
region. Histopathology demonstrates subepidermal, non-acantholytic blisters. Direct 
immunofluorescence for IgG and C3 shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above image showing linear IgG and C3 deposits on direct immunofluorescence (DIF) 
microscopy is characteristic of bullous pemphigoid. Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by tense itchy bulla in the flexor areas and trunk which do 
not rupture easily. In bullous pemphigoid, the antibodies are formed against bullous pemphigoid 
antigens (BPAGs)- BP 180 and BP 230, which are components of hemidesmosomes. The separation of bullous pemphigoid from pemphigus is based on the identification 
of subepidermal, nonacantholytic blisters that are Nikolsky negative. Nikolsky's sign is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or 
perilesional skin. If the lesion is opened (i.e., skin sloughed off), then the Nikolsky's sign is 
present/positive. 1283 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: A 28-year-old man with gluten sensitivity presents with severely itchy papulovesicular lesions 
on extremities, knees, elbows, and buttocks for one year. Direct immunofluorescence staining 
of the lesions showed IgA deposition as follows. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above image showing granular deposits of IgA on direct immunofluorescence is suggestive 
of dermatitis herpetiformis or Duhring's disease. These deposits localize in the tips of dermal 
papillae. Dermatitis herpetiformis presents as grouped vesicles and papules. These lesions are commonly 
located over the extensor aspects of knees, elbows, buttocks, back, scalp which are associated with 
intense pruritus. It is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy or celiac disease. It is also associated with HLA 
DQ2/DQ8/B8. Deposition of IgA antitransglutaminase antibodies in the dermal papillae results in 
true subepidermal blisters and vesicles. The characteristic microscopic feature is subepidermal blisters with papillary tip 
microabscesses containing neutrophils. The initial treatment of choice for dermatitis herpetiformis is a gluten-free diet. The image below shows subepidermal vesicles, with papillary neutrophil microabscesses, with 
neutrophil, eosinophil and lymphocytes infiltrates in the superficial dermis in case of dermatitis 
herpetiformis. 1284 
Sold by @itachibot The image below shows vesicular lesions of dermatitis herpetiformis. 1285 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A 36-year-old male with skin-colored umbilicated papules. Microscopy is as shown below. 
The most likely diagnosis is 
. 1263 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given microscopic image shows large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells 
of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum. Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin caused by a 
poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is about 300 nm in size, the largest pathogenic poxvirus in 
humans Tzanck smear shows intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson–Patterson bodies), the 
largest known inclusion bodies (30–35 m). Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules (shown below). A 
curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication 1286 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: A pathology resident notes the following cells while examining a histopathological section. It 
may be seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.explanation:
The image above shows Touton giant cells having a central ring of nuclei while the peripheral 
cytoplasm is clear due to accumulated lipid. These cells are formed by the fusion of 
lipid-containing macrophages. They are not seen in sarcoidosis. These cells are seen in: • Fat necrosis • Xanthoma • Xanthogranulomas • Dermatofibroma The cardinal histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis is the non-caseating epithelioid granuloma 
with occasional other microscopic features: • Schaumann bodies - laminated concretions composed of calcium and proteins • Asteroid bodies - stellate inclusions enclosed within giant cells

questions.question:
Question 20: A 35-year-old man presented with a single hypoaesthetic and a hypopigmented patch on the 
lateral aspect of the forearm. Microscopy of a biopsy sample from the lesion revealed 
granulomatous inflammation but acid-fast bacilli were not identified. What is the likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is tuberculoid leprosy. On microscopic examination, tuberculoid leprosy has granulomatous lesions closely resembling 
those found in tuberculosis. Because of the strong host defense, bacilli are almost never found, 
hence the name paucibacillary leprosy. Leprosy or Hansen disease is a slowly progressive infection caused by 
Mycobacterium leprae, mainly affecting the skin and peripheral nerves. 1287 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: A 25-year-old man from the eastern part of India presents with a shallow and slowly 
expanding ulcer with heaped-up borders over the face. Biopsy reveals granulomas and the 
following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The image shows many histiocytes containing Leishman–Donovan bodies and surrounding 
chronic inflammatory cells classically seen in cutaneous leishmaniasis. Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer, often with 
heaped-up borders. On microscopic examination, the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation, usually with many 
giant cells and few parasites. Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by a single skin nodule, which continues 
spreading until the entire body is covered by nodular lesions. Microscopically, they contain 
aggregates of foamy macrophages stuffed with leishmania.

questions.question: Question 22: Max Joseph’s space is a histopathological feature of which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Max Joseph’s space is a histopathological feature of lichen planus. Histological features of lichen planus: • Orthokeratosis, parakeratosis, thickening of the stratum granulosum. • Acanthosis with the formation of colloid bodies (also known as Civatte bodies/Sabouraud bodies) • Liquefactive degeneration of the stratum basale, with separation from the underlying lamina 
propria, as a result of desmosome loss, creating small spaces (Max Joseph spaces) • Infiltration of T cells in a band-like pattern into the dermis “hugging” the basal layer (interface 
dermatitis) 1288 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 23: A 35-year-old man presents with the following lesions. Which of the following finding is likely 
to be seen in histopathology?
questions.explanation:
The image shows silvery-white scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the knees suggestive of 
psoriasis. Munro microabscesses are seen in psoriasis. Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory dermatosis that appears to have an autoimmune basis. The 
lesions are pink to salmon-colored plaque covered by loosely adherent silver-white scales. Auspitz 
sign and Koebner phenomenon can be demonstrated. Nail changes include pitting, dimpling, 
separation of the nail plate, onycholysis, thickening, and crumbling. Microscopy shows thinning of stratum granulosum, supra papillary plates, and neutrophils 
forming small aggregates within the superficial epidermis (spongiform pustules) and within the 
stratum corneum (Munro microabscesses). Some types of microabscesses and their examples are given below: Predominant cell
